docs.lead_paragraph: Kicking off the latest chapter of this year's Full Employment Act for K Street Lobbyists, representatives from a surfeit of industries descended on an influential Congressional committee on Wednesday as it began writing a law overhauling the nation's regulatory system.

headline.main: Lobbyists Mass to Try to Shape Financial Reform

docs.abstract: Kicking off the latest chapter of this year's Full Employment Act for K Street Lobbyists, representatives from a surfeit of industries descended on an influential Congressional committee on Wednesday as it began writing a law overhauling the nation's regulatory system.
docs.snippet: Kicking off the latest chapter of this year's Full Employment Act for K Street Lobbyists, representatives from a surfeit of industries descended on an influential Congressional committee on Wednesday as it began writing a law overhauling the nation's...

docs.lead_paragraph: During much of the health care debate this year, the insurance industry has been the dog that didn't bark. But with the emergence of specific legislation from the Senate Finance Committee, that has changed.
docs.abstract: During much of the health care debate this year, the insurance industry has been the dog that didn't bark. But with the emergence of specific legislation from the Senate Finance Committee, that has changed.
docs.snippet: During much of the health care debate this year, the insurance industry has been the dog that didn't bark. But with the emergence of specific legislation from the Senate Finance Committee, that has changed.

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the biggest challenges facing lawmakers who favor universal health care coverage is coming up with a plan for the 20-somethings, the so-called young invincibles.

headline.main: What Congress Plans for the Young and Uninsured

docs.abstract: The 'young invincibles' aren't sure they need health insurance. Democrats think otherwise.
docs.snippet: The 'young invincibles' aren't sure they need health insurance. Democrats think otherwise.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lost in the hullabaloo on Tuesday, what with a Republican on the Senate Finance Committee voting for the panel's health care legislation, was the news that Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, an independent who caucuses with the Democrats, came out against the bill.
docs.abstract: A senator turns against health care legislation from the Senate Finance Committee.
docs.snippet: A senator turns against health care legislation from the Senate Finance Committee.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since the Finance Committee voted in favor of a health care bill, pressure has been building among liberal and progressive groups who are doubling down on a public insurance option in the Democratic bills. Several bloggers and advocates were by turn incensed and galvanized by the laudatory sentiments expressed by Democratic lawmakers toward Senator Olympia Snowe, the Maine Republican whose vote on Tuesday helped move a health care bill without such a plan out of the Finance Committee.

headline.main: BlogTalk: Redoubling on a Public Option

docs.abstract: Yesterday's health vote spurred a flurry of traffic and fund-raising on Web sites over trying to salvage a public option in the health care bills.
docs.snippet: Yesterday's health vote spurred a flurry of traffic and fund-raising on Web sites over trying to salvage a public option in the health care bills.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Executives of AARP, the huge organization for older Americans, acknowledged on Wednesday that they have a big job in trying to sell health care reforms to their members, and that the work will not end if President Obama signs a bill into law.

headline.main: AARP Says Its Chore Is Educating Members on Bill's Benefits

docs.abstract: Executives of AARP say they have a "communications challenge" in educating people that the Medicare savings proposed by Democrats to help finance expanded coverage will not cut their benefits.
docs.snippet: Executives of AARP say they have a "communications challenge" in educating people that the Medicare savings proposed by Democrats to help finance expanded coverage will not cut their benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a rare appearance as a witness at a Senate hearing, the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, told the Judiciary Committee on Wednesday that it should repeal a 1945 law that granted the insurance industry limited exemption to national antitrust laws by allowing states to regulate insurers.

headline.main: For Insurers, a Question of Trust (and Antitrust)

docs.abstract: Senate majority leader Harry Reid calls for an end to the insurance industry's limited exemption from antitrust law.
docs.snippet: Senate majority leader Harry Reid calls for an end to the insurance industry's limited exemption from antitrust law.

docs.lead_paragraph: The following is a transcript of President Obama’s remarks on Tuesday after the Senate Finance Committee became the fifth Congressional panel to report out a health care bill.
docs.snippet: The following is a transcript of President Obama’s remarks on Tuesday after the Senate Finance Committee became the fifth Congressional panel to report out a health care bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks were narrowly mixed on Tuesday as traders waited for some of the country's largest banks to declare how they performed over the summer, The New York Times's Jack Healy reported.

headline.main: Shares Wander Ahead of Bank Earnings

docs.abstract: Stocks were narrowly mixed on Tuesday as traders waited for some of the largest U.S. banks to declare how they performed over the summer.
docs.snippet: Stocks were narrowly mixed on Tuesday as traders waited for some of the largest U.S. banks to declare how they performed over the summer.
